summary: .  Merchant Marine of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act (Sec. 3) This bill requires the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the award, on behalf of Congress, of a single gold medal to the U.S. Merchant Marine of World War II, in recognition of their dedicated and vital service during World War II.  Following its award the medal shall be given to the American Merchant Marine Museum where it will be available for display and research.
predicted_summary: Directs the Secretary of Transportation, acting through the Maritime Administration, to award a gold medal to the U.S. merchant marine personnel who, during their service, were integral in providing combat equipment, fuel, food, commodities, and raw materials to troops stationed overseas.Directs the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives to make appropriate arrangements for the presentation, on behalf of the Government of the United States, of a gold medal to the U.S. Merchant Marine Corps in recognition of its service during World War II, particularly its role in ensuring the efficient and reliable transoceanic transport of military equipment and personnel despite consistent and ongoing exposure to enemy combatants from both air and the sea.TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: American Merchant Marine <n> Tile II: Women's Merchant Marine; <n>Title I: Americans Merchant Marine<n> - Directs the Secretary of the department in which the merchant marine is operating to issue regulations governing all operations of U.S. merchant marine vessels during World War II, including those in support of contingency operations. <n>Requires all merchant marine officers and men serving in contingency operations to be granted a leave of absence from duty during such period of service to enable them to perform their duties.The congressional gold medal is an appropriate way to shed further light on the service of the merchant marine in world war ii and the instrumental role they played in winning world war II.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 22, 2008. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Authorizes the Department of the Treasury to strike and sell duplicates in bronze of the gold medal struck under this Act at a price sufficient to cover the costs of the medals, including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, and overhead expenses.

summary: Small Business Modernization Act of 2004 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) terminate subchapter S corporation elections after 2004 and subchapter S status after 2014 and to allow privately-held domestic corporations, in lieu of electing subchapter S treatment, to elect to be treated as partnerships for tax purposes; (2) set forth rules for the tax treatment of former subchapter S corporations electing partnership status; and (3) exclude from net earnings from self-employment partnership income attributable to capital.
predicted_summary: (This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on March 6, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend the election made by certain corporations to be taxed as partnership to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004.Exempts an s corporation from the alternative minimum tax if it makes an election to be treated as a partnership for federal tax purposes during the period beginning on the date of the election and ending three years after the date on which the s Corporation becomes a partnership.Defines "eligible corporation" as a domestic corporation no stock of which is readily tradable on an established securities market or otherwise, and which is not an ineligible corporation.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for the tax treatment of a corporate taxpayer electing unified pass-thru regime as defined by this Act. (Currently, such tax treatment is provided only with respect to a pass-through entity.)Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise the tax treatment of: (1) s corporation electing unified pass-thru regime; (2) earnings and profits purposes; and (3) estates and trusts.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise the tax treatment of built-in gains on dispositions of certain depreciable property over a ten-year recognition period.Provides that if, on the date of an election by a corporation, the ten-year period specified in clause I with respect to such corporation has expired, clause I shall not apply to it.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from capital income the distributive share of net income of a partner attributable to capital. (Currently, such income is excluded from gross income.)Provides that if the partner acquires a partnership interest and the partnership makes an election, the reasonable rate of return on unreturned capital shall be a reasonable rate on un Returned Capital: (1) means the excess of the aggregate amount of money and the fair market value as of the date of contribution of other consideration contributed by the partner over the aggregate amounts of money, and the Fair Market Value as ofthe date of distribution of otherConsideration distributed by the partnership to the partner, increased or decreased for the partner's distributive share of all reportable items; and (2) means actuariariariariatropolis, defined as any district of New York State which has a population of less than 200,000, and any district in which more than 200,000 persons are required by State law to register with the Secretary of the Treasury.The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to services performed in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004. (Sec. 3) This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify the definition of a service for purposes of the tax deduction for certain expenses of registered nurses, physicians, and other health care providers by allowing the deduction of expenses incurred for providing medical services without a prescription, if the service is performed in a taxable year and the deduction is applicable to a service performed in any taxable year beginning after 2004.

summary: Fair Access to Investment Research Act of 2016 This bill directs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to revise a specified regulation to create a safe harbor for certain publications or distributions of research reports by brokers or dealers distributing securities. The revised regulation shall declare that a published or distributed investment fund research report shall not be deemed to constitute an offer for sale or an offer to sell a security that is the subject of the offering pursuant to an effective registration statement, even if the broker or dealer is participating or will participate in the registered offering of the covered investment fund's securities. The covered investment fund research report shall indeed be deemed to satisfy the regulation's requirements as well as those of any self-regulatory organization. The SEC shall not impose specified conditions and requirements when implementing the safe harbor.  Until the SEC has adopted such safe harbor revisions, and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) has revised a related rule, a covered investment fund shall be deemed to be a security listed on a national securities exchange that is not subject to a certain filing requirement of the Investment Company Act of 1940.
predicted_summary: Instructs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to propose to adopt regulations to provide that a covered investment fund research report that is published or distributed by a broker or dealer shall be deemed to be: (1) published by a Broker or dealer; and (2) distributed by an broker or dealers, without regard as to whether or not the research is disseminated by the broker or Dealer.Declares that the implementation of a safe harbor for covered investment funds is in the public interest and consistent with the purposes and duties of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), as well as any self-regulatory organization.The minimum float provision of a self-regulatory organization may not be imposed for any period exceeding the period of time referenced in specified federal regulations, or to prohibit the ability of a member to participate in a registered offering or other distribution of securities of a covered investment fund solely because the member has published or distributed a covered Investment Fund research report about such covered Investment fund or its securities.The application of the antifraud or antimanipulation provisions of the federal securities laws and rules adopted thereunder to a covered investment fund research report is limited to the extent that it is otherwise not subject to the content standards in the rules of any self-regulatory organization related to research reports, including those contained in the Rules governing communications with the public regarding investment companies or substantially similar standards.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 12, 2009. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, respectively, to grant the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regulatory authority over securities dealers and investment funds, including the authority to prohibit the sale or delivery of any security if the SEC finds that the transaction constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice.<n><n>Prescribes guidelines under which the SEC may: (1) refer an alleged violation to another entity; (2) prohibit the SEC from taking an enforcement action unless it first provides the entity with a reasonable opportunity to submit written notice of the violation; and (3) permit the SEC to assess and collect fees from violators of its rules, without regard to whether such violations were committed knowingly or willfully.Directs the Securities and Exchange Commission to deem to be a security listed on a national securities exchange, and not subject to specified laws of the investment company Act of 1940, any security that is listed on such exchange and that is not, according to the Act, subject to mandatory registration as a security by an investment company under such Act.The dealer about a covered investment fund or any securities issued by the covered investment Fund, but does not include a research report to the extent that the research report is published or distributed by thecovered investment fund, or any affiliate, of the covered Investment Fund.Securities Act of 1933 - Amends the securities act of 1933 to replace references to "research report" with references to the term "self-regulatory organization," except that such term shall not include an oral communication.

summary:
Outer Continental Shelf Revenue Sharing Act of 2005 - Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act (OCSLA) regarding the coastal impact assistance program to: (1) repeal references to leasing moratoria; (2) redefine a "producing state" as one that begins production on a leased tract on or after the date of enactment of this Act, regardless of whether the leased tract was on any date subject to a leasing moratorium; (3) repeal the exclusion of certain revenues from "qualified Outer Continental Shelf revenues;" and (4) repeal the exclusion of certain leased tracts from the statutory formula for payments to coastal political subdivisions.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to delineate the lateral boundaries between coastal states in areas of the Outer Continental Shelf under exclusive federal jurisdiction.

Prescribes guidelines for petitions to lease within the seaward lateral boundaries of coastal states.

Includes guidelines under which a state shall share in qualified Outer Continental Shelf revenues as of the date production begins under this Act.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to issue implementing regulations, including procedures for entering into gas-only leases.
predicted_summary: Outer Continental Shelf Revenue Sharing Act of 2005 - Amends the outer continental shelf revenue sharing act of 2005 to repeal the requirement that the Secretary of the Interior report to specified congressional committees on specified aspects of the outer Continental Shelf (OCS) program.The Secretary of Commerce shall delineate the lateral boundaries between coastal states in areas of the outer continental shelf under exclusive federal jurisdiction to the extent of the exclusive economic zone of the United States.Amends the outer continental shelf lands Act to authorize leasing within the seaward lateral boundaries of coastal states, including California, Oregon, and Washington. (Currently, this authority applies only to Alaska.)Authorizes the governor of a state in which an affected area is located, with the consent of the state's legislature, to submit to the Secretary of the Interior a petition requesting a resource assessment of any area within the seaward lateral boundary of the State.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to approve a petition to require a resource assessment of a state area unless such assessment would create an unreasonable risk of harm to the state's marine, human, or coastal environment, unless the Secretary determines that such an assessment would.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 6, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to authorize the Secretary of the Interior to acquire lands within the seaward lateral boundaries of a state, and greater than 20 miles from the coastline of the state, for the conduct of offshore leasing, pre-leasing, or related activities with respect to oil and gas leasing, gas-only leasing, or any other energy source leasing, including renewable energy leasing.Prescribes a revenue sharing formula, with a special exception for states receiving revenues from political subdivisions.<n>Requires any appropriate area to be made available for oil and gas leasing, gas-only leasing, or any other energy source leasing, renewable energy leasing.Declares that nothing in this Act affects any right relating to an area described in clause (1) or (2) under a lease that was in existence on the day before enactment of this Act. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to issue necessary regulations, including regulations establishing procedures for entering into gas-only leases.(b) any mixture of natural or artificial gas (including compressed or liquefied petroleum gas) and condensate recovered from natural gas. (Sec. 3) Makes it out of order in the Senate to consider any legislation that would authorize the use of federal funds to acquire any property or interest in property used in the manufacture, production, or distribution of any fuel or petroleum product if: (1) the property or interests in property are owned by the federal government, or (2) the acquisition would occur solely as a result of an agreement between the government and a private person.

summary:
Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to revise due process standards governing the accreditation process of educational institutions.

 Requires accrediting agencies and associations to provide educational institutions with: (1) written notice of deficiencies and a reasonable time period to correct such deficiencies; (2) advance notice of any adverse action and an opportunity for a hearing; and (3) a right to appeal an adverse action to an independent and impartial arbitration panel.

Requires accrediting agencies and associations to: (1) ensure consistent application of accreditation standards to an educational institution's governing board in receivership; and (2) allow public access to meetings involving accreditation recommendations.

Authorizes the Secretary of Education to issue regulations to further define due process requirements for the accreditation process.
predicted_summary: Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to require institutions of higher education (IHEs) and postsecondary vocational institutions (except religious schools) that are members of a cooperative education association, or that are participating in a program sponsored by such an association, to participate in the accrediting process in accordance with specified procedures of that association or agency.Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to prohibit an agency or association from assessing the compliance of an accredited institution with its own policies and procedures and the extent to which a decision was tainted by bias or prejudice.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 10, 2003.) The term "meetings" includes all meetings, hearings, appeals, deliberations, and votes on accreditation matters regarding any educational institution or on accrediting standards, policies, or procedures; and (a) such assessment shall consistently apply the accreditation standard to any state-appointed receiver, special trustee, or similar interim governing authority, until such time as governing authority is returned to the regular governing board, and (b) such agency or association shall conduct meetings open to public observation.Amends Federal law to extend through FY 1991 the authorization of appropriations for grants for the recognition of State accrediting agencies for purposes of Federal standards and requirements.
